pr_title: Iterate type interfaces without materialising a list during super type matching

timeline.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText: This looks suspicious - IINM it is valid to call it.next(); it.next(); it.next(); and expect to get the next value on each invocation (or get an exception). But here calling next() without hasNext() being called first will return still the same element.
timeline.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: It's a private static class intended for local usage only, I would prefer to add a comment than change this
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText:
Ok. Out of curiosity - why is it important that you cache the next value? To avoid the interfaces set check?
Sorry for bikesheding - does it need to be an actual Iterator implementation?
replies.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: I want to halt the iteration as soon as an exception is thrown. I don't want to check if there is another element, catch an exception in the call to next() and then handle it elsewhere. In fact, this peculiarity is the reason for returning Iterable - to force orderly iteration.
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: What about throwing UnsupportedOperationException to make it totally clear that this method is not supposed to be called at all.
timeline.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText: Nit: maybe final to discourage brave souls extending this class?
timeline.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText: Is it ok not to do null check?
timeline.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: These are bytebuddy types. As far as I'm aware, the library will throw exceptions rather than produce null values.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: So I'm wondering if this has something to do with the Netty failure. From digging into ByteBuddy a bit it seems like the default equals for those types work on getName and not getSimpleName
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: I know that this comment and behavior is the same as the old one, but maybe clarify that it stops at the first exception.
timeline.author: bantonsson
bantonsson

replies.bodyText: Is name sufficient here?  We have to be a bit carefully about duplicates being loaded across different ClassLoaders, but in a limited context, name should work.
replies.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: I think I'll just change this back to HashSet to avoid edge cases.
replies.author: richardstartin
